conclusion: Acceleration is defined as the rate of change of velocity with respect to time: a = dv/dt
On a v-t graph, acceleration is represented by the slope of the velocity curve.
Positive slope indicates positive acceleration, negative slope indicates negative acceleration (deceleration), and steeper slope indicates greater magnitude of acceleration.
Object B's velocity curve is represented by the curved line that starts at the origin (0,0).
Object B's velocity curve decreases initially (has negative slope) until time t1.
At t1, Object B's velocity reaches its minimum value (most negative velocity).
After t1, Object B's velocity increases (has positive slope) until t2.
The curve appears to be concave upward throughout the interval.

premise: The slope of curve B is negative and becoming less steep from 0 to t1.
conclusion: This indicates a negative acceleration that is becoming less negative (increasing).

premise: The slope of curve B changes from negative to positive at t1 and continues to increase from t1 to t2.
conclusion: This indicates a positive acceleration that is increasing in magnitude.

premise: Considering the entire interval from 0 to t2: The acceleration starts as negative, passes through zero at time t1, and becomes positive and continues to increase until t2.
conclusion: The trend of the acceleration of object B during the time interval 0 to t2 is continuously increasing.
